intro: Acanthodium capense, commonly known as the Cape acanthodium, is a small, flowering plant native to South Africa. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is often found in coastal regions. Its flowers are usually yellow or orange, and it produces small, spiny bracts that give it its distinctive appearance. Acanthodium capense is adapted to arid conditions and is often used in rock gardens due to its hardy nature.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acanthodium capense is primarily native to South Africa, specifically the Western and Northern Cape provinces. It is commonly found in rocky outcrops and sandy soils within these regions. The plant thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in open, sunny areas. It is a member of the Asteraceae family and is known for its distinctive yellow flowers. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is not widely distributed beyond its native range.
